I.   THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE FACILITY 
 
A.  Justification 
 
1.  Rationale 
 
1.  The Asian Development Bank (ADB) has had a fruitful partnership with Uzbekistan on 
urban development for two decades, particularly in the water supply and sanitation (WSS) sector, 
a relationship which is deepening and expanding in scope, both on project finance and sector 
reforms.  Achievements  have  been  accomplished  in  utility  management,  water  quality 
management, and financial sustainability. Extensive experience has been gained in effective 
project  design  and  implementation.  ADB’s  assistance  has  been  closely  aligned  with  the 
government’s evolving development priorities, to improve living conditions, create a sustainable 
environment, and strengthen economic competitiveness. To date, more than 5 million residents 
(more than 15% of the population) are benefitting from the assistance. Since 1997, ADB has 
provided loan financing of more than $700.0 million for eleven investment projects in the sector, 
and grant funding of $2.5 million for sector enhancement (Appendix 4). 
 
2.  Significant development challenges remain. Despite strong economic growth,1 which is 
particularly attributable to urban areas, the country suffers from persistent WSS service limitations 
in both urban and rural areas. The nation’s Soviet-era centralized wastewater systems are 
dilapidated and as a result, vast quantities of untreated wastewater are discharged into rivers, 
surface impoundments, and groundwater resources. Surface water pollutants often far exceeds 
maximum  allowable  concentrations.  Networks  and  treatment  facilities  need  immediate 
rehabilitation.  These  deficiencies  have  resulted  in  WSS  service  inequalities,  environmental 
deterioration, and public health threats, in turn causing constrained economic growth. Traditional 
separation of gender roles where women are primarily responsible for domestic chores results in 
women’s poverty, and the lack of reliable WSS service increases this burden. Urban areas already 
face the challenges of having aging public infrastructure, unreliable public services, and limited 
financial resources now face additional stress due to rapid population growth.  
 
3.  ADB will apply a comprehensive and programmatic approach to develop more integrated 
urban development solutions. The transaction TA facility will provide project preparation support 
to a series of ensuing projects, comprising: (i) Tashkent Province Sewerage Improvement Project 
($160 million); (ii) Uzbekistan Water Supply and Sanitation Development Program ($200 million)2; 
(iii) Uzbekistan Integrated Urban Development Project ($200 million); and (iv) Uzbekistan Solid 
Waste Management Development Project ($150 million) (Appendix 3). The transaction TA facility 
will support improvement of WSS and other public services through technical, policy, and capacity 
development, in both urban and rural areas. Uzbekistan now has stronger country systems and 
capacity and using the principle-based sector program approach will give the country a greater 
sense of ownership. An integrated approach will be applied to the development of economic 
growth clusters with stronger urban rural linkages. Support in these areas, including tourism 
development, will cover urban planning and management, urban rural linkages and provision of 
public services, cultural heritage protection, information and communications technology, public-
                                                
1   Uzbekistan is one of Central West Asia’s fastest growing economies, and aspires to become an upper-middle-income 
nation. Its gross domestic product has grown consistently at over 7% annually to 2016, and growth is predicted at 
over 5% annually through to at least 2019. Strategic investments in local infrastructure are considered essential to 
meet national development objectives. 
2  Results-Based Lending (RBL) and Sector Development Program (SDP) modalities are being explored for the 
program.

2 
 
private partnership arrangements, and small and medium-sized enterprises (SME) and women 
business enterprise (WBE) development. 
 
  2.  Program of Ensuing Projects  
 
4.  Programmatic approach for urban development. Following ADB’s earlier support in the 
WSS sector, the government has emphasized the need for ADB support through a strategic and 
coordinated sequence of projects, that would create synergy between investments and technical 
assistance, strengthening the impact of the proposed assistance. The approach will focus on 
priority interventions that will target the key WSS and urban development issues. It will contain 
innovative features, including high technology applications, and advancing the readiness for 
public-private partnership arrangements. This approach will ensure that ADB’s investments will 
play a catalytic role in the government’s broader urban development program. 
 
5.  Ensuing Projects. The support is broadly based. It includes project loans and TA to                     
(i) improve the urban services and environment; (ii) to make cities in Uzbekistan more liveable 
with better public service; and (iii) to stimulate inclusive and sustainable economic growth through 
integrated  approach  and  strengthened  urban  rural  linkages,  rehabilitated  and  upgraded 
infrastructure and strengthened institutional and management capacity (Table 1).   
   
Table 1: Program of Ensuing Projects 
Ensuing Projects    Description 
Tashkent Province Sewerage  The project will upgrade the centralized wastewater systems in six cities and one 
Improvement Project   urban center by rehabilitating/upgrading six existing wastewater treatment plants 
and rehabilitating/expanding sewer coverage. It will also improve sanitation 
practices in rural areas, and strengthen management and operational capacity of 
Tashkent Provincial Suvokova (TPS). The project is consistent with the ADB 
Water Operational Plan 2011–2020,3 and the ADB Country Operations Business 
Plan, 2018–2020 for Uzbekistan.4 It also aligns with previous and ongoing ADB-
funded WSS sector projects in Uzbekistan and contributes to the attainment of 
Sustainable Development Goal 6: Clean Water and Sanitation. The project 
impacts are environment, health and living conditions in Tashkent Province 
improved. The project outcome: access to reliable, sustainable and affordable 
wastewater services improved and expanded in the project area. The total 
estimated cost is $185.0 million. The government has requested ADB for a $160.0 
million loan which is included in ADB’s lending pipeline for 2019.  
Uzbekistan Water Supply and  The project will support part of a national WSS development program. ADB will 
Sanitation Development  support several investments of the fourteen regional water companies in the 
Program  northeastern part of the country. The primary investments are to be selected from 
the following: (i) replacement of pumps for improved energy efficiency; (ii) 
installation of production meters; (iii) installation of water meters (targeting 
100%); (iv) reduction of inflow/infiltration in sewer networks; (v) equipment for 
water quality monitoring; (vi) nonrevenue water reduction; and (vii) hydrological 
modelling. ADB funding, as a portion of investments of the national program, is 
estimated at $200 million.   
Uzbekistan Integrated Urban  The project will focus primarily on environmentally-sustainable, socially inclusive, 
Development Project  and integrated urban development in selected cities, with investments in key 
municipal infrastructure and services, SME promotion and development, and 
environmental management for improved livability in the cities. The project will 
also improve capacity in urban planning, utility management, ICT, and PPP. The 
project is to be funded by ADB at an estimated cost of $200 million.  
                                                
3   ADB. 2011. Water Operational Plan 2011-2020. Manila. The project supports wastewater management investments.  
4  ADB. 2017. Uzbekistan: Country Operations Business Plan (2018-2020). Manila. The project supports the key drivers 
of change relating to governance, knowledge management, gender equity, and climate change and the environment.

3 
 
Uzbekistan Solid Waste  The project will improve solid waste management and promote PPP in solid 
Management Development  waste sector. The main outputs are solid waste collection and disposal improved; 
Project  solid waste amount reduced through improved recycling and waste-to-energy 
mechanisms;  and  cost-effective  operation  and  maintenance  achieved.  The 
project is to be funded by ADB at an estimated cost of $150 million. 
ADB = Asian Development Bank, ICT= information and communications technology, PPP = public-private partnership, 
SME = small and medium-sized enterprises, WBE = women business enterprise, WSS = water supply and sanitation. 
Source: Asian Development Bank estimates.  
 
3.  Transaction Technical Assistance Facility’s Roles and Justifications 
 
6.  The transaction TA facility will help to prepare these interrelated projects and TA. It will 
ensure a consistent approach to urban development, address cross-sectoral themes, develop 
local capacity for improved project implementation, enhance project readiness, and strengthen 
overall coordination and cooperation for the country’s sustainable urban development. The design 
of the transaction TA facility follows ADB’s sector and thematic operational plans, namely the 
Water Operational Plan 2011–2020, Urban Operational Plan 2012–2020, and the Environmental 
Operational Directions 2013–2020 and will contribute to key operation priorities such as liveable 
cities,  governance  and  institutional  capacity  improvement,  and  environmental  sustainability 
enhancement under Strategy 2030.5  
 
B.  Outputs and Activities   
 
7.  The outcome of the transaction TA facility will be the investment and TA projects suitable 
for ADB financing prepared. It will deliver four key outputs for each ensuing project. 
 
8.  Output 1: Technical feasibility assessments conducted and technical specifications 
prepared. This output will ensure that project activities improve inclusive and environmentally 
sustainable growth. Key activities will include: (i) activity selection for the ensuing projects 
prepared; (ii) comprehensive feasibility studies undertaken; and (iii) project baselines specified. 
Detailed surveys, data collection activities, including collection of sex-disaggregated data for 
baselines, and other elements to be supported by each project will be undertaken to define:                      
(i) baselines and gaps for enhancing billing efficiency, application of smart technologies for 
reducing power consumption, and improving asset management and operational efficiencies; and 
(ii) in case of RBL program, disbursement-linked indicators and related verification processes.  
 
9.  Output 2: Safeguard due diligence of the ensuing projects and documentation 
completed. This output will support the review and document preparation for project-related 
safeguards due diligence to meet ADB’s Safeguards Policy Statement (2009) requirements. Key 
activities are the preparation and implementation of: (i) stakeholder analyses, participation plans 
and stakeholder workshops; (ii) social and gender impact assessments; (iii) resettlement plans 
and  ethnic  minority  development  plans;  (iv)  social,  poverty,  and  gender  assessments;  (v) 
institutional capacity building plans; and (vi) project initial environmental examinations. 
 
10.  Output 3: Investment plans and procurement packages prepared. This output will 
include economic, financial and governance due diligence for project preparations, including: (i) 
financial  and  economic  analyses; (ii) financial management  assessments  of  executing  and 
implementing agencies; (iii) project cost estimates; (iv) procurement plans; and (v) procurement 
capacity assessments of executing and implementing agencies.  
                                                
5  ADB. 2011. Water Operational Plan, 2011-2020. Manila; ADB. 2013. Urban Operational Plan, 2012–2020. Manila; 
ADB. 2013. Environmental Operational Directions, 2013–2020. Manila; ADB. 2018. Strategy 2030. Manila.

4 
 
11.  Output 4: Sustainable business model and institutional capacity developed through 
prioritized  interventions  including  (i)  design  of  business  models  covering  corporate  plan, 
operational,  institutional  restructuring,  and  human  resources  management;  (ii)  options  for 
accountability and incentive mechanisms, with a performance benchmarking matrix; (iii) capacity 
building recommendations for executing and implementing agencies; and (iv) development of:                
(a) a pilot scale Geographic Information System (GIS) to initiate GIS capacity; (b) computerized 
hydraulic modeling for network design management and river water quality monitoring; (c) a pilot 
operations and maintenance (O&M) program using advanced technology; and (d) a re-education 
program in collaboration with the Ministry of Education for advanced study in water supply and 
sanitation. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
  
12.  The transaction TA facility is estimated to cost $3.0 million, to be financed on a grant basis 
by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other sources), and administered by ADB. 
The transaction TA facility funds will be allocated among ensuing projects which will be updated 
based  on  country  operations  business  plan  exercise.  The  $0.8  million  to  support  project 
preparation of Tashkent Province Sewerage Improvement Project will be allocated in 2019. The 
remaining TASF will be allocated later once the resources are available. The overall cost 
estimates, financing plan, and key expenditure items are listed in Appendix 1. For each project 
TA, the government will provide counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff, and the 
provision of relevant government data and studies for the TA consultants’ use. The government 
has been informed that approval of the transaction TA facility of project TAs does not commit ADB 
to finance any ensuing project.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements  
 
13.  ADB’s Central and West Asia Department, Urban Development and Water Division will 
coordinate and administer the transaction TA facility and TA projects, working closely with 
designated counterparts. Each ensuing transaction TA projects will commence only after ADB 
approval of its respective concept paper. Other implementation arrangements are summarized in 
Table 2.  
 
Table 2: Implementation Arrangements

14.  The TRTA facility will be implemented through a series of TA projects (Table 3), to be 
identified and updated in the country operations business plan. Each project TA will deliver the 
key four outputs, specific to its ensuing project.

15.  Consulting services. International and national consultants will be engaged to complete 
all TA projects. The indicative consultants’ input allocation is shown in Appendix 2. These 
estimates will be finalized in consultation with the government. 
  
16.  The consulting firm and individual consultants will be recruited based on the requirements 
of each TA project. The consulting firm will be engaged in accordance with the quality- and cost-
based selection method, with a quality-cost ratio of 90:10 using full, simplified, or bio-data 
technical  proposal.  Individual  consultants  will  be  selected  using  the  individual  consultant’s 
selection method to provide specialized technical and administrative inputs to fulfil ADB due 
diligence requirements and enhance project readiness. The recruitment of all consultants will be 
carried out in accordance with ADB’s Procurement Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) 
and its associated project administration instructions and/or staff instructions. Lump-sum or 
output-based contracts will be considered for consulting services, consistent with ADB’s Strategy 
2030,6 to reduce administrative burden and improve the economy, efficiency, and value for 
money. The consultants will procure any goods and equipment purchased under the TA and will 
turn them over to the executing agency at or before the completion of the TA. 
 
  II.   THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
 
17.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $3,000,000 on a grant basis to 
the  Government  of  the  Republic  of  Uzbekistan  for  Preparing  Urban  Development  and 
Improvement Projects, and hereby reports this action to the Board. 
 
                                                
6 ADB 2018. Strategy 2030. Manila.
